name: 2-bromo-4-cyanopyridine
Reason: 2-bromo-4-cyanopyridine has a melting point influenced by its functional groups relative to the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a bromine atom, which can increase the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the capacity for hydrogen bonding. The cyano group can also contribute to the melting point due to its ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +2 °C for this functional group.
